Literature Review: The Deepwater Horizon oil spill in 2010 was a catastrophic event that highlighted the complexities of oil transport in the ocean. The spill, which occurred on April 20, 2010, released an estimated 4.9 million barrels of crude oil into the Gulf of Mexico, causing widespread environmental damage and economic losses exceeding $50 billion. The oil spill was characterized by a complex mixture of oil droplets, gas bubbles, and suspended particles, which interacted with the surrounding water to form a dynamic plume. Understanding the behavior of this plume is crucial for predicting the extent of oil spreading and dispersion, as well as for developing effective strategies for oil spill response and mitigation. The formation of oil droplets is a critical process in the oil spill process. Research has shown that the size distribution of oil droplets plays a significant role in determining the rate of oil spreading and dispersion. Studies have used various methods, including optical microscopy and droplet size analysis, to investigate the formation of oil droplets in the Deepwater Horizon spill. These studies have shown that the oil droplets formed in the spill were typically in the range of 10-100 micrometers in diameter, with a median diameter of around 50 micrometers. The behavior of oil droplets on the water surface is also an important aspect of oil transport. Research has shown that oil droplets can interact with the water surface to form a dynamic layer of oil, which can affect the rate of oil spreading and dispersion. Studies have used various methods, including laboratory experiments and numerical modeling, to investigate the behavior of oil droplets on the water surface. Massive drifter experiments have been conducted in the Gulf of Mexico to study the behavior of oil droplets in the ocean. These experiments have used a combination of laboratory and field experiments to investigate the behavior of oil droplets in different environmental conditions. The results of these experiments have shown that the behavior of oil droplets in the ocean is highly dependent on the environmental conditions, including the wind speed, wave height, and water temperature. The impact of the Mississippi River on the oil transport is also an important aspect of the Deepwater Horizon spill. Research has shown that the Mississippi River can play a significant role in transporting oil from the Gulf of Mexico to other parts of the United States. Studies have used various methods, including numerical modeling and field experiments, to investigate the impact of the Mississippi River on the oil transport. Finally, the formation of oil-particle aggregates is an important process in the oil spill process. Research has shown that oil-particle aggregates can form in the ocean, which can affect the rate of oil spreading and dispersion. Studies have used various methods, including laboratory experiments and numerical modeling, to investigate the formation of oil-particle aggregates. In conclusion, the Deepwater Horizon oil spill was a complex event that highlighted the importance of understanding the behavior of oil droplets and oil-particle aggregates in the ocean. By elucidating the physical processes involved in oil transport, we can develop more effective strategies for oil spill response and mitigation.
